title: Final Project demo Website
text:
Question 1

Question 1.1: Which illness is most common?

health_clean %>%
  group_by(illness)%>%
  summarise(mean= mean(percentage), mean_high= mean(percentage_high), mean_low= mean(percentage_low))%>%
  ungroup()%>%
  mutate(mean=mean/100, mean_high= mean_high/100, mean_low= mean_low/100)%>%
  mutate(labels=scales::percent(mean))%>%
  ggplot(aes(illness, mean, fill=illness))+
  geom_col(position = "dodge")+
  geom_errorbar(aes(ymin=mean_low,ymax=mean_high))+
  scale_x_discrete(name= "Illness")+
  scale_y_continuous(limits= range(0,0.3), label = scales::percent, name = "Percentage of mean")+
  scale_fill_discrete(name= "Illness")+
   ggthemes::theme_few()+
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle=90))+
  theme(legend.position = "bottom", legend.key.size = unit(0.1, 'cm'), legend.text = element_text(size=7), legend.title = element_text(size=10))+
  geom_text(aes(label = labels), size=3, vjust=-.5)+
  labs(title = "Mean For Various Illness")+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust=0.5))




According to the graphic above, “Hay fever or respiratory allergy among persons under 18 years” is the most common illness.


Question 1.2 In this particular illness, how does the percentage for demographic characteristics change over time?

health_clean %>%
  filter(str_detect(illness,"respiratory"))%>%
  mutate(percentage= percentage/100)%>%
   ggplot(aes(year_number, percentage, col=sub_name))+
 geom_line()+
  facet_wrap(vars(characteristics), labeller = label_wrap_gen(width=25))+
  ggthemes::theme_few()+
  scale_x_continuous(n.break=8, name= "Year Number")+
  scale_y_continuous(label = scales::percent, name = "Percentage of characteristics")+
  scale_color_discrete(name= "Sub-name of characteristics")+
   guides(col=guide_legend(nrow=6))+
  theme(legend.position = "bottom", legend.key.size = unit(0.1, 'cm'), legend.text = element_text(size=7), legend.title = element_text(size=6))+
  labs(title = "Percentages for various characteristics-Hay fever or respiratory allergy")+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust=0.5))+
  theme(strip.text = element_text(size=7))




According to the graphic, the trends for all characteristics overtime are going down, except the “Two or more races” in the “Race” category.


Questions 1.3 What do the demographic characteristics look like?

Insurance Level

health_clean %>%
  filter(str_detect(illness,"respiratory")& str_detect(characteristics, "insurance"))%>%
  group_by(sub_name)%>%
  summarise(mean= mean(percentage),mean_high= mean(percentage_high), mean_low= mean(percentage_low))%>%
  ungroup()%>%
  mutate(mean=mean/100, mean_high= mean_high/100, mean_low= mean_low/100)%>%
  mutate(labels=scales::percent(mean))%>%
  ggplot(aes(sub_name, mean, fill=sub_name))+
  geom_col(position = "dodge")+
  geom_errorbar(aes(ymin=mean_low,ymax=mean_high))+
scale_x_discrete(name= "Insurance Status")+
  scale_y_continuous(limits= range(0,0.25),label = scales::percent, name = "Percentage of mean")+
  scale_fill_discrete(name= "Health insurance status at the time of interview")+
   ggthemes::theme_few()+
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")+
  geom_text(aes(label = labels), size=5, vjust=-1)+
  labs(title = "Mean percentage for various insuranced categories and uninsured category-Hay fever or respiratory allergy")+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust=0.5))




According to the graphic, the “Insured: Private” have the highest percentage of mean.

health_clean %>%
  filter(str_detect(illness,"respiratory")& str_detect(characteristics, "insurance"))%>%
  mutate(sub_name= str_remove(sub_name, ": Medicaid$|: Private$"))%>%
  group_by(sub_name)%>%
  summarise(mean= mean(percentage),mean_high= mean(percentage_high), mean_low= mean(percentage_low))%>%
  ungroup()%>%
  mutate(mean=mean/100, mean_high= mean_high/100, mean_low= mean_low/100)%>%
  mutate(labels=scales::percent(mean))%>%
  ggplot(aes(sub_name, mean, fill=sub_name))+
  geom_col(position = "dodge")+
scale_x_discrete(name= "Insurance Status- Insured and Uninsured")+
  geom_errorbar(aes(ymin=mean_low,ymax=mean_high))+
  scale_y_continuous(limits= range(0,0.25),label = scales::percent, name = "Percentage of mean")+
  scale_fill_discrete(name= "Health insruance status")+
  geom_errorbar(aes(ymin=mean_low,ymax=mean_high))+
   ggthemes::theme_few()+
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")+
  geom_text(aes(label = labels), size=5, vjust=-1)+
  labs(title = "Mean percentage for insured and uninsured-Hay fever or respiratory allergy")+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust=0.5))




According to the graphic, mean percentage for children who are in the Insured status is higher than those who are not.


Poverty Level

health_clean %>%
  filter(str_detect(illness,"respiratory")& str_detect(characteristics , "poverty"))%>%
   mutate(sub_name=factor(sub_name,levels=c("Below 100%", "100%-199%", "200%-399%","400% or more"))) %>%
  group_by(sub_name)%>%
  summarise(mean= mean(percentage), mean_high= mean(percentage_high), mean_low= mean(percentage_low))%>%
  ungroup()%>%
  mutate(mean=mean/100, mean_high= mean_high/100, mean_low= mean_low/100)%>%
  mutate(labels=scales::percent(mean))%>%
  ggplot(aes(sub_name, mean, fill=sub_name))+
  geom_col(position = "dodge")+
geom_errorbar(aes(ymin=mean_low,ymax=mean_high))+
scale_x_discrete(name= "Percent of poverty level")+
  scale_y_continuous(limits= range(0,0.3),label = scales::percent, name = "Percentage of mean")+
  scale_fill_discrete(name= "Percent of poverty level")+
   ggthemes::theme_few()+
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")+
  geom_text(aes(label = labels), size=5, vjust=-1)+
  labs(title = "Mean percentage for various poverty level-Hay fever or respiratory allergy")+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust=0.5))




According to the graphic, “400% or more” have the highest percentage rate.


Race

health_clean %>%
  filter(str_detect(illness,"respiratory")& str_detect(characteristics, "Race"))%>%
  group_by(sub_name)%>%
  summarise(mean= mean(percentage), median=median(percentage), mean_high= mean(percentage_high), mean_low= mean(percentage_low))%>%
  ungroup()%>%
  mutate(mean=mean/100, median= median/100, mean_high= mean_high/100, mean_low= mean_low/100)%>%
  mutate(labels=scales::percent(mean))%>%
  ggplot(aes(sub_name, mean, fill=sub_name))+
  geom_col(position = "dodge")+
scale_x_discrete(name= "Race")+
  scale_y_continuous(limits= range(0,0.3),label = scales::percent, name = "Percentage of mean")+
  scale_fill_discrete(name= "Race")+
   ggthemes::theme_few()+
  guides(fill=guide_legend(nrow=3))+
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle=90))+
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")+
  geom_text(aes(label = labels), size=5, vjust=-1)+
  labs(title = "Mean percentage for various race-Hay fever or respiratory allergy")+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust=0.5))




According to the graphic, “400% or more” have the highest percentage rate.


Sex

health_clean %>%
  filter(str_detect(illness,"respiratory")& str_detect(characteristics, "Sex"))%>%
  group_by(sub_name)%>%
  summarise(mean= mean(percentage), mean_high= mean(percentage_high), mean_low= mean(percentage_low))%>%
  ungroup()%>%
  mutate(mean=mean/100, mean_high= mean_high/100, mean_low= mean_low/100)%>%
  mutate(labels=scales::percent(mean))%>%
  ggplot(aes(sub_name, mean, fill=sub_name))+
  geom_col(position = "dodge")+
  geom_errorbar(aes(ymin=mean_low,ymax=mean_high))+
scale_x_discrete(name= "Sex")+
  scale_y_continuous(limits= range(0,0.3),label = scales::percent, name = "Percentage of mean")+
  scale_fill_discrete(name= "Sex")+
   ggthemes::theme_few()+
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle=90))+
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")+
  geom_text(aes(label = labels), size=5, vjust=-1)+
  labs(title = "Mean percentage for Sex-Hay fever or respiratory allergy")+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust=0.5))




According to the graphic, the “Male” have higher mean percentage.


Age

health_clean %>%
  filter(str_detect(illness,"respiratory")& str_detect(characteristics, "Age"))%>%
   mutate(sub_name=factor(sub_name,levels=c("0-4 years", "5-17 years","5-9 years", "10-17 years")))%>%
  group_by(sub_name)%>%
  summarise(mean= mean(percentage), median=median(percentage), mean_high= mean(percentage_high), mean_low= mean(percentage_low))%>%
  ungroup()%>%
  mutate(mean=mean/100, median= median/100, mean_high= mean_high/100, mean_low= mean_low/100)%>%
  mutate(labels=scales::percent(mean))%>%
  ggplot(aes(sub_name, mean, fill=sub_name))+
  geom_col(position = "dodge")+
  geom_errorbar(aes(ymin=mean_low,ymax=mean_high))+
scale_x_discrete(name= "Age")+
  scale_y_continuous(limits= range(0,0.3),label = scales::percent, name = "Percentage of mean")+
  scale_fill_discrete(name= "Age")+
   ggthemes::theme_few()+
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle=90))+
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")+
  geom_text(aes(label = labels), size=5, vjust=-1)+
  labs(title = "Mean percentage for Age-Hay fever or respiratory allergy")+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust=0.5))




According to the graphic, the “10-17 years old” have higher mean percentage.
##Question 2



Question 2.1 Which percentage of illness increased most over time?

health_clean %>%
  group_by(illness, year, `year_number`)%>%
  summarise(mean= mean(percentage), median=median(percentage))%>%
  ungroup()%>%
  mutate(mean=mean/100, median= median/100)%>%
  mutate(labels=scales::percent(mean))%>%
  ggplot(aes(year_number, mean, col= illness))+
  geom_path()+
  ggthemes::theme_few()+
  scale_x_continuous(n.break=8, name= "Year Number")+
  scale_y_continuous(label = scales::percent, name = "Percentage of illness")+
  scale_color_discrete(name= "Illness")+
   guides(col=guide_legend(nrow=4))+
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")+
  labs(title = "Trends For Various Illness overtime")+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust=0.5))+
  theme(strip.text = element_text(size=7))




According to the graphic,Skin Allergy is the illness that increase most overtime.


Question 2.2 How does the percentage of demographic characteristics change over time in this particular illness?

health_clean %>%
  filter(str_detect(illness,"Skin"))%>%
  mutate(percentage= percentage/100)%>%
   ggplot(aes(year_number, percentage, col=sub_name))+
 geom_line()+
  facet_wrap(vars(characteristics), labeller = label_wrap_gen(width=25), scale= "free")+
  ggthemes::theme_few()+
  scale_x_continuous(n.break=8, name= "Year Number")+
  scale_y_continuous(label = scales::percent, name = "Percentage of characteristics")+
  scale_color_discrete(name= "Sub-name of characteristics")+
   guides(col=guide_legend(nrow=6))+
  theme(legend.position = "bottom", legend.key.size = unit(0.1, 'cm'), legend.text = element_text(size=7), legend.title = element_text(size=6))+
  labs(title = "Percentages for various characteristics")+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust=0.5))+
  theme(strip.text = element_text(size=7))




According to the graphic, almost all the demographic characteristics are in the increased trend overtime.

According to the graphic, besides “Food allergy”, “Skin allergy”, and “ADHD”, other illness are seems in the decline trends overtime.


Question 3.2 Can we define which illness is most common among those in “insured” status and those not?

health_clean %>%
  filter(str_detect(characteristics,"insurance")) %>%
   mutate(sub_name= str_remove(sub_name, ": Medicaid$|: Private$"))%>%
  group_by(illness, sub_name)%>%
  summarise(mean= mean(percentage), mean_high= mean(percentage_high), mean_low= mean(percentage_low))%>%
  ungroup()%>%
  mutate(mean=mean/100,mean_high= mean_high/100, mean_low= mean_low/100)%>%
  mutate(labels=scales::percent(mean)) %>%
ggplot(aes(sub_name, mean,fill=sub_name))+
  geom_col(position = "dodge")+
  facet_wrap(vars(illness), labeller = label_wrap_gen(width=25))+
scale_x_discrete(name= "Insurance Status")+

  scale_fill_discrete(name= "Insurance Status")+
   ggthemes::theme_few()+

  geom_text(aes(label = labels), size=5, vjust=-1)+
  labs(title = "Mean percentage for various insuance status-various illness")+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust=0.5))




According to the graphic, “Hay fever or respiratory allergy” is the most common illness among those in “insured” status and those not.

scale_x_discrete(name= "Percent of poverty level")+

According to the graphic, “Hay fever or respiratory allergy” is the most common illness among those in various poverty level.

title: Final Project- Demo
text:
Question 1

Question 1.1 How to combine the “Insured” sub-categories?

insured_uninsured_calculate <- function(x) {

table <- health_clean %>%
  filter(str_detect(illness, x)& str_detect(characteristics, "insurance"))%>%
  mutate(sub_name= str_remove(sub_name, ": Medicaid$|: Private$"))

 Insured <- table %>%
  filter(str_detect(sub_name,"Insured")) %>%
group_by(illness, characteristics, sub_name, year, year_number) %>%
  summarise(percentage= sum(percentage), percentage_high= sum(percentage_high), percentage_low= sum(percentage_low))

 Uninsured <- table %>%
  filter(str_detect(sub_name,"Uninsured"))%>%
   select(!se)
 
 table_final <- full_join(Insured, Uninsured)%>%
  mutate(percentage= percentage/100)%>%
    mutate(percentage_high=percentage_high/100)%>%
    mutate(percentage_low= percentage_low/100)
 
 return(table_final)}

illness_variable <- unique(health_clean$illness)

table_final_illness<- map_dfr(illness_variable, insured_uninsured_calculate)

table_final_illness



  



As mentioned in the “Overview” section, combine three categories under “Insured,” meaning full. Accordingly, this section uses functions like str_remove() and summaries(sum()) to achieve it.


Question 1.2 which insurance status is higher? Insured or Uninsured?

median_percentage_insured_uninsured <- table_final_illness%>%
  group_by(year, year_number, sub_name)%>%
  summarise(median=median(percentage))

median_percentage_insured_uninsured



  


median_percentage_insured_uninsured %>%
  ggplot(aes(year_number, median, col=sub_name))+
  geom_line()+
  geom_point()+
  ggthemes::theme_few()+
  scale_x_continuous(n.break=14, name= "Year Number")+
  scale_y_continuous(label = scales::percent, name = " Median percentage for various insruance status", n.breaks = 10)+
  scale_color_okabeito(name="Insurance Status")+
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")+
  labs(title = "Trends For Various Insurance Status Overtime")+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust=0.5))+
  theme(strip.text = element_text(size=7))




Based on the graphic above, it is easy to see that insured status has a higher median percentage.


Question 1.3 Which illness is more prevalent based on these two statuses?

insured_uninsured_viualization <- function(x){
  table_final_illness %>%
  filter(str_detect(sub_name, x)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(year_number, percentage, col=illness))+
  geom_line()+
  geom_point()+
  ggthemes::theme_few()+
  scale_x_continuous(n.break=14, name= "Year Number")+
  scale_y_continuous(label = scales::percent, name = "Percentage of Illness", n.breaks = 10)+
  scale_color_brewer(palette = "Set2", name= "Illness")+
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust=0.5))+
    guides(col=guide_legend(nrow=4))
    }


Insured_graphic <- insured_uninsured_viualization("Insured")+
  labs(title = "Percentage For Various Illness Overtime Based On Insured Status")

Insured_graphic



 Uninsured_graphic <- insured_uninsured_viualization("Uninsured")+
  labs(title = "Percentage For Various Illness Overtime Based On Uninsured Status")

Uninsured_graphic



insured_uninsured_find_highest <- function(x) {

table_final_illness%>%
  filter(str_detect(sub_name, x))%>%
  group_by(illness)%>%
  summarise(max=max(percentage), min=min(percentage)) %>%
  ungroup()%>%
  summarise(highest_maximum= max(max), highest_minimal=max(min))
}

insured_uninsured_find_highest("Insured")



  


Insured_graphic+
  gghighlight(percentage<0.54, percentage>0.44)+
  labs(title = "Most Prevalence Illness Overtime- Insured")



insured_uninsured_find_highest("Uninsured")



  


Uninsured_graphic+
  gghighlight(percentage<0.16, percentage>0.109, label_key=illness)+
  labs(title = "Most Prevalence Illness Overtime- Uninsured")




According to the graphic above, “Hay fever or respiratory allergy” is the most common illness for both “Insured” and “Uninsured” status.

illness_median%>%

According to the graphic above, “Hay fever or respiratory allergy” is the most common illness.


Question 3.2 How does the percentage for different demographic characteristics change over time in this particular illness?

characteristic_division_respiratory <- function(x) {
health_clean %>%
  filter(str_detect(illness,"respiratory"))%>%
  mutate(percentage= percentage/100)%>%
    mutate(percentage_high=percentage_high/100)%>%
    mutate(percentage_low= percentage_low/100)%>%
  filter(str_detect(characteristics,x)) }

Visualization <- function (df) {
  
  df%>%
   ggplot(aes(year_number, percentage, col=sub_name))+
 geom_line()+
    geom_point()+
  ggthemes::theme_few()+

section: How to combine the insured sub-category?
text:
How to combine the insured sub-category?

insured_uninsured_calculate <- function(x) {

table <- health_clean %>%
  filter(str_detect(illness, x)& str_detect(characteristics, "insurance"))%>%
  mutate(sub_name= str_remove(sub_name, ": Medicaid$|: Private$"))

 Insured <- table %>%
  filter(str_detect(sub_name,"Insured")) %>%
group_by(illness, characteristics, sub_name, year, year_number) %>%
  summarise(percentage= sum(percentage), percentage_high= sum(percentage_high), percentage_low= sum(percentage_low))

 Uninsured <- table %>%
  filter(str_detect(sub_name,"Uninsured"))%>%
   select(!se)
 
 table_final <- full_join(Insured, Uninsured)%>%
  mutate(percentage= percentage/100)%>%
    mutate(percentage_high=percentage_high/100)%>%
    mutate(percentage_low= percentage_low/100)
 
 return(table_final)}

illness_variable <- unique(health_clean$illness)

table_final_illness<- map_dfr(illness_variable, insured_uninsured_calculate)

table_final_illness

title: Final Project- Demo
text:
Overview
The data set includes 16 columns. The column “INDICATOR” consists of the information about the whole data set, which is “Health conditions among children under age 18” and is a characteristic variable. The column “PANEL” is a characteristic variable and includes information about various health issues. The column “PANEL_NUM” represents the code for different health issues. The column “UNIT” indicates the number in the data set focused on percentage. “UNIT_NUM” refers to the code representing the characteristic variables in the “UNIT” column. “STUB_NAME” includes different characteristics for the respondents, like age, race, sex, etc., and the “STUB_NAME_NUM” shows the codes related to them. “STUB_LABEL” means the sub-variables related to the characteristics, like different age groups, female and male for the gender, and column “STUB_LABEL_NUM” involves the number representing them. “YEAR” includes information about different year stages, “YEAR_NUM” represents them, “AGE” and “AGE_NUM” include different age stages and numbers represent them, “ESTIMATE” is the number percent of children, “SE” means the standard error. In the “FLAG” column, “—” means the data is not available, and “*” means the estimate might not be reliable.
A document provided by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) provides some important notes for the data set. The demographic characteristics “Total” include information for all other races that are not shown separately and the unknown insurance status(“Health Conditions Among Children Under Age 18, by Selected Characteristics: United States, Average Annual, Selected Years 19971999 Through 20162018” 2019a). Besides, the categories in the “Insurance status” characteristics are mutually exclusive, which means that the “Insured” category does not cover the information provided in the “Insured: private” and “Insured: Medicaid.” It means that combining these three categories for future analysis is appropriate(“Health Conditions Among Children Under Age 18, by Selected Characteristics: United States, Average Annual, Selected Years 19971999 Through 20162018” 2019a).
To clean the data, delete the columns that include some repeat information, like the number representing the variables, the columns that only include one piece of information, like the “INDICATOR” column, and the rows that contain the not available cells, are necessary. Besides, arranging the table through “PANEL” and “YEAR,” renaming the column, and using the information in the “SE” column (standard error) to calculate the upper and lower percentage information will make the table more in order and easier to understand.

health_clean <- health %>%
  select(- ("PANEL_NUM"),
         - ("UNIT_NUM"),
         -("STUB_NAME_NUM"),
         -("STUB_LABEL_NUM"),
         -("AGE_NUM"),
         - ("INDICATOR"),
         - ("UNIT"),
         - ("AGE"),
         - ("FLAG"))%>%
  arrange(PANEL, YEAR)%>%
  na.omit()%>%
  rename("illness"=`PANEL`, "characteristics"=`STUB_NAME`, "sub_name"=`STUB_LABEL`, "year"= `YEAR`, "year_number"= `YEAR_NUM`, "percentage"=`ESTIMATE`, "se"=`SE`) %>%
   mutate(illness= str_remove(illness, "among persons under 18 years"))%>%
  mutate("percentage_high"= percentage+se, "percentage_low"= percentage-se )
  

health_clean

title: Final Project- Demo
text:
Summary the numerical variables- percentage
To summarize the numerical variables “percentage” (or percent of the students), grouping the variable into the different demographic categories based on various illnesses is necessary. The summary includes information about the central tendency of the percentage, including the mean and median. It aims to describe the center of distribution of data(Conway, n.d.b). The summary also includes range, standard deviation, maximum, minimum, and quartile information. It shows the variability or the differences between values in this numerical variable and can determine whether or not the variable “percentage” contains the extreme variable [Conway (n.d.c)](“3.2 - Identifying Outliers: IQR Method,” n.d.).
The formula used to determine the extreme variable, or outlier, is:

IQR = Q3 – Q1
upper fence=Q3 + (1.5 * IQR)
lower fence=Q1 – (1.5 * IQR)
(“3.2 - Identifying Outliers: IQR Method,” n.d.)


q = c(.25, .5, .75)
numerical_summary_table <- function(x) {
  health_clean%>%
  filter(str_detect(illness,x)) %>%
  group_by (characteristics, year) %>%
  summarise(mean_percentage= mean(percentage), median_percentage=median(percentage), sd_percentage= sd(percentage),range_percentage= max(percentage)-min(percentage), max_percentage= max(percentage), min_percentage= min(percentage), quant25 = quantile(percentage, na.rm=TRUE,probs = q[1]), quant50 = quantile(percentage,na.rm=TRUE, probs = q[2]),quant75 = quantile(percentage,na.rm=TRUE, probs = q[3]))%>%
mutate(IQR=quant75- quant25,extrem_value_range_percentage_max= quant75 + (1.5 * IQR),extrem_value_range_percentage_min= quant25-(1.5 * IQR))

}

find_extrem_value_high<- function(df) {

df%>%
  filter(max_percentage>extrem_value_range_percentage_max) }

find_extrem_value_low<- function(df) {
df%>%
  filter(min_percentage<extrem_value_range_percentage_min) }

title: Final Project- Demo
section: which insurance status is higher? Insured or Uninsured?
text:
which insurance status is higher? Insured or Uninsured?

median_percentage_insured_uninsured <- table_final_illness%>%
  group_by(year, year_number, sub_name)%>%
  summarise(median=median(percentage))

median_percentage_insured_uninsured



  


median_percentage_insured_uninsured %>%
  ggplot(aes(year_number, median, col=sub_name))+
  geom_line()+
  geom_point()+
  ggthemes::theme_few()+
  scale_x_continuous(n.break=14, name= "Year Number")+
  scale_y_continuous(label = scales::percent, name = " Median percentage for various insruance status")+
  scale_color_discrete(name="Insurance Status")+
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")+
  labs(title = "Trends For Various Insurance Status Overtime")+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust=0.5))+
  theme(strip.text = element_text(size=7))





Which illness is more prevalent based on these two statuses?

insured_uninsured_viualization <- function(x){
  table_final_illness %>%
  filter(str_detect(sub_name, x)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(year_number, percentage, col=illness))+
  geom_line()+
  geom_point()+
  ggthemes::theme_few()+
  scale_x_continuous(n.break=8, name= "Year Number")+
  scale_y_continuous(label = scales::percent, name = "Percentage of Illness", n.breaks = 10)+
    geom_errorbar(aes(ymin=percentage_high,ymax=percentage_low, width=0.5))+
  scale_color_brewer(palette = "Paired", name= "Illness")+
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust=0.5))+
    guides(col=guide_legend(nrow=4))
    }

Insured_graphic <- insured_uninsured_viualization("Insured")+
  labs(title = "Percentage For Various Illness Overtime Based On Insured Status")

Insured_graphic



 Uninsured_graphic <- insured_uninsured_viualization("Uninsured")+
  labs(title = "Percentage For Various Illness Overtime Based On Uninsured Status")

Uninsured_graphic



insured_uninsured_find_highest <- function(x) {

table_final_illness%>%
  filter(str_detect(sub_name, x))%>%
  group_by(illness)%>%
  summarise(max=max(percentage), min=min(percentage)) %>%
  ungroup()%>%
  summarise(highest_maximum= max(max), highest_minimal=max(min))
}

insured_uninsured_find_highest("Insured")



  


Insured_graphic+
  gghighlight(percentage<0.54, percentage>0.44)+
  labs(title = "Most prevalence illness overtime- Insured")



insured_uninsured_find_highest("Uninsured")



  


Uninsured_graphic+
  gghighlight(percentage<0.16, percentage>0.109, label_key=illness)+
  labs(title = "Most prevalence illness overtime- Uninsured")

title: Final Project- Demo
text:
Question 2

Question 2.1 What does the percent in the poverty level categories mean? How do we reorder the categories based on the definition?
The percentage is computed using U.S. Census Bureau poverty thresholds and family income and size information(“Health Conditions Among Children Under Age 18, by Selected Characteristics: United States, Average Annual, Selected Years 19971999 Through 20162018” 2019b). It can used to set the “poverty lines.” (“2024 Federal Poverty Levels / Guidelines & How They Determine Medicaid Eligibility” 2024). The way to understand the percentage could be, for instance, the annual income for the “400% or more” percentage level is four times the annual income for the 100% level. Accordingly, the order for the categories within the poverty level should be “Below 100%”, “100%-199%”, “200%-399%”, and “400% or more.”

reorder_poverty_level <- health_clean %>%
  filter(str_detect(characteristics , "poverty"))%>%
   mutate(sub_name=factor(sub_name,levels=c("Below 100%", "100%-199%", "200%-399%","400% or more")))

reorder_poverty_level



  





Question 2.2 Which poverty level has a higher percentage?

poverty_level<- reorder_poverty_level%>%
  group_by(sub_name, year, year_number)%>%
  summarise(median= median(percentage))%>%
  mutate(median= median/100)

poverty_level %>%
  ggplot(aes(year_number, median, col=sub_name))+
  geom_line()+
  geom_point()+
  ggthemes::theme_few()+
  scale_x_continuous(n.break=14, name= "Year Number")+
  scale_y_continuous(label = scales::percent, name = " Median Percentage for various poverty level", n.breaks = 10)+
  scale_color_discrete(name="poverty level")+
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")+
  labs(title = "Trends For Various Poverty Level Overtime")+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust=0.5))+
  theme(strip.text = element_text(size=7))+
   guides(col=guide_legend(nrow=2))




The graphic above shows that the “100% and below” poverty level has a higher median percentage.


Question 2.3 Which illness is more prevalent based on various poverty levels?

poverty_level_visualization <- function (x) {

health_clean %>%
  filter(str_detect(characteristics, "poverty"))%>%
  filter(str_detect(sub_name, x))%>%
    mutate(percentage=percentage/100)%>%
    mutate(percentage_high=percentage_high/100)%>%
    mutate(percentage_low=percentage_low/100)%>%
  ggplot(aes(year_number, percentage, col=illness))+
  geom_line()+
  geom_point()+
  ggthemes::theme_few()+
  scale_x_continuous(n.break=14, name= "Year Number")+
  scale_y_continuous(label = scales::percent, name = "Percentage of Illness", n.breaks = 10)+
  scale_color_brewer(palette = "Set2", name= "Illness")+
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust=0.5))+
    guides(col=guide_legend(nrow=4))
}

unique(poverty_level$sub_name)

[1] Below 100%   100%-199%    200%-399%    400% or more
Levels: Below 100% 100%-199% 200%-399% 400% or more

`Below 100% graphic` <- poverty_level_visualization ("Below 100%")+
  labs(title = "Percentage Of Below 100% Overtime For Various Illness")

`Below 100% graphic`



`100%-199% graphic` <- poverty_level_visualization ("100%-199%")+
   labs(title = "Percentage Of 100%-199% Overtime For Various Illness")

`100%-199% graphic` 



`200%-399% graphic` <- poverty_level_visualization("200%-399%")+
  labs(title = "Percentage Of 200%-399% Overtime For Various Illness")

`200%-399% graphic`



`400% or more graphic`<- poverty_level_visualization("400% or more")+

poverty_level_find_highest <- function(x) {


health_clean %>%
  filter(str_detect(characteristics, "poverty"))%>%
  filter(str_detect(sub_name, x))%>%
    mutate(percentage=percentage/100)%>%
    mutate(percentage_high=percentage_high/100)%>%
    mutate(percentage_low=percentage_low/100)%>%
  group_by(illness)%>%
  summarise(max=max(percentage), min=min(percentage)) %>%
  ungroup()%>%
    arrange(desc(max))
}

poverty_level_find_highest("Below 100%")



  


`Below 100% graphic`+
  gghighlight(max(percentage)== 0.149)+
  labs(title = "Most Prevalence Illness Overtime- Below 100%")

poverty_level_find_highest("200%-399%")



  


`200%-399% graphic`+
  gghighlight(max(percentage)== 0.185)+
  labs(title = "Most Prevalence Illness Overtime- 200%-399%")

`400% or more graphic`+
  gghighlight(min(percentage)>0.16)+

section: About the year and year number
text:
About the year and year number
As the “year” is the categorical variable and represents the range of years, it might not be suitable to use it to show the trend of the percentage of children changing over time by using the liner graphic. Instead, the year_number is a numerical variable and includes the information for various year ranges, so using it in future analysis is more appropriate. This section aims to show how the information in the “year” column matches the information in the “year_number” column, which hopes to make the graphic below easier to understand.

unique(health_clean$year)%>%
  as.data.frame()%>%
  rename("Year Range"= ".") %>%
mutate(Number= unique(health_clean$year_number))

title: Final Project- Demo
text:
Overview
The data set includes 16 columns. The column “INDICATOR” consists of the information about the whole data set, which is “Health conditions among children under age 18” and is a characteristic variable. The column “PANEL” is a characteristic variable and includes information about various health issues. The column “PANEL_NUM” represents the code for different health issues. The column “UNIT” indicates the number in the data set focused on percentage. “UNIT_NUM” refers to the code representing the characteristic variables in the “UNIT” column. “STUB_NAME” includes different characteristics for the respondents, like age, race, sex, etc., and the “STUB_NAME_NUM” shows the codes related to them. “STUB_LABEL” means the sub-variables related to the characteristics, like different age groups, female and male for the gender, and column “STUB_LABEL_NUM” involves the number representing them. “YEAR” includes information about different year stages, “YEAR_NUM” represents them, “AGE” and “AGE_NUM” include different age stages and numbers represent them, “ESTIMATE” is the number percent of children, “SE” means the standard error. In the “FLAG” column, “—” means the data is not available, and “*” means the estimate might not be reliable.
A document provided by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) provides some important notes for the data set. The demographic characteristics “Total” include information for all other races that are not shown separately and the unknown insurance status(“Health Conditions Among Children Under Age 18, by Selected Characteristics: United States, Average Annual, Selected Years 19971999 Through 20162018” 2019). Besides, the categories in the “Insurance status” characteristics are mutually exclusive, which means that the “Insured” category does not cover the information provided in the “Insured: private” and “Insured: Medicaid.” It means that combining these three categories for future analysis is appropriate(“Health Conditions Among Children Under Age 18, by Selected Characteristics: United States, Average Annual, Selected Years 19971999 Through 20162018” 2019).

title: Final Project- Demo
text:
Summary the numerical variables- percentage
To summarize the numerical variables “percentage” (or percent of the students), grouping the variable into the different demographic categories based on various illnesses is necessary. The summary includes information about the central tendency of the percentage, including the mean and median. It aims to describe the center of distribution of data(Conway, n.d.b). The summary also includes range, standard deviation, maximum, minimum, and quartile information. It shows the variability or the differences between values in this numerical variable and can determine whether or not the variable “percentage” contains the extreme variable(Conway, n.d.b) (“3.2 - Identifying Outliers: IQR Method,” n.d.).
The formula used to determine the extreme variable, or outlier, is:

IQR = Q3 – Q1
upper fence=Q3 + (1.5 * IQR)
lower fence=Q1 – (1.5 * IQR)
(“3.2 - Identifying Outliers: IQR Method,” n.d.)


q = c(.25, .5, .75)
numerical_summary_table <- function(x) {
  health_clean%>%
  filter(str_detect(illness,x)) %>%
  group_by (characteristics, year) %>%
  summarise(mean_percentage= mean(percentage), median_percentage=median(percentage), sd_percentage= sd(percentage),range_percentage= max(percentage)-min(percentage), max_percentage= max(percentage), min_percentage= min(percentage), quant25 = quantile(percentage, na.rm=TRUE,probs = q[1]), quant50 = quantile(percentage,na.rm=TRUE, probs = q[2]),quant75 = quantile(percentage,na.rm=TRUE, probs = q[3]))%>%
mutate(IQR=quant75- quant25,extrem_value_range_percentage_max= quant75 + (1.5 * IQR),extrem_value_range_percentage_min= quant25-(1.5 * IQR))

}

find_extrem_value_high<- function(df) {

df%>%
  filter(max_percentage>extrem_value_range_percentage_max) }

find_extrem_value_low<- function(df) {
df%>%
  filter(min_percentage<extrem_value_range_percentage_min) }

find_extrem_value_high(ADHD_numerical_summary)

objectID: Final project-Health conditions among children under age 18.html#about-the-year-and-year-number
href: Final project-Health conditions among children under age 18.html#about-the-year-and-year-number
title: Final Project- Demo
section: About the year and year number
text:
About the year and year number
As the “year” is the categorical variable and represents the range of years, it might not be suitable to use it to show the trend of the percentage of children changing over time by using the liner graphic. Instead, the year_number is a numerical variable and includes the information for various year ranges, so using it in future analysis is more appropriate. This section aims to show how the information in the “year” column matches the information in the “year_number” column, which hopes to make the graphic below easier to understand.

unique(health_clean$year)%>%
  as.data.frame()%>%
  rename("Year Range"= ".") %>%
mutate(Number= unique(health_clean$year_number))

objectID: Final project-Health conditions among children under age 18.html#question-1
href: Final project-Health conditions among children under age 18.html#question-1
title: Final Project- Demo
text:
Question 1

Question 1.1 How to combine the “Insured” sub-categories?

insured_uninsured_calculate <- function(x) {

table <- health_clean %>%
  filter(str_detect(illness, x)& str_detect(characteristics, "insurance"))%>%
  mutate(sub_name= str_remove(sub_name, ": Medicaid$|: Private$"))

 Insured <- table %>%
  filter(str_detect(sub_name,"Insured")) %>%
group_by(illness, characteristics, sub_name, year, year_number) %>%
  summarise(percentage= sum(percentage), percentage_high= sum(percentage_high), percentage_low= sum(percentage_low))

 Uninsured <- table %>%
  filter(str_detect(sub_name,"Uninsured"))%>%
   select(!se)
 
 table_final <- full_join(Insured, Uninsured)%>%
  mutate(percentage= percentage/100)%>%
    mutate(percentage_high=percentage_high/100)%>%
    mutate(percentage_low= percentage_low/100)
 
 return(table_final)}

illness_variable <- unique(health_clean$illness)

table_final_illness<- map_dfr(illness_variable, insured_uninsured_calculate)

table_final_illness



  



As mentioned in the “Overview” section, combine three categories under “Insured,” meaning full. Accordingly, this section uses functions like str_remove() and summaries(sum()) to achieve it.


Question 1.2 which insurance status is higher? Insured or Uninsured?

median_percentage_insured_uninsured <- table_final_illness%>%
  group_by(year, year_number, sub_name)%>%
  summarise(median=median(percentage))

median_percentage_insured_uninsured



  


median_percentage_insured_uninsured %>%
  ggplot(aes(year_number, median, col=sub_name))+
  geom_line()+
  geom_point()+
  ggthemes::theme_few()+
  scale_x_continuous(n.break=14, name= "Year Number")+
  scale_y_continuous(label = scales::percent, name = " Median percentage for various insruance status", n.breaks = 10)+
  scale_color_okabeito(name="Insurance Status")+
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")+
  labs(title = "Trends For Various Insurance Status Over Time")+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust=0.5))+
  theme(strip.text = element_text(size=7))




Based on the graphic above, it is easy to see that insured status has a higher median percentage.


Question 1.3 Which illness is more prevalent based on these two statuses?

insured_uninsured_viualization <- function(x){
  table_final_illness %>%
  filter(str_detect(sub_name, x)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(year_number, percentage, col=illness))+
  geom_line()+
  geom_point()+
  ggthemes::theme_few()+
  scale_x_continuous(n.break=14, name= "Year Number")+
  scale_y_continuous(label = scales::percent, name = "Percentage of Illness", n.breaks = 10)+
  scale_color_brewer(palette = "Set2", name= "Illness")+
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust=0.5))+
    guides(col=guide_legend(nrow=4))
    }


Insured_graphic <- insured_uninsured_viualization("Insured")+
  labs(title = "Percentage For Various Illness Over Time Based On Insured Status")

Insured_graphic



 Uninsured_graphic <- insured_uninsured_viualization("Uninsured")+
  labs(title = "Percentage For Various Illness Over Time Based On Uninsured Status")

Uninsured_graphic



insured_uninsured_find_highest <- function(x) {

table_final_illness%>%
  filter(str_detect(sub_name, x))%>%
  group_by(illness)%>%
  summarise(max=max(percentage), min=min(percentage)) %>%
  ungroup()%>%
  summarise(highest_maximum= max(max), highest_minimal=max(min))
}

insured_uninsured_find_highest("Insured")



  


Insured_graphic+
  gghighlight(percentage<0.54, percentage>0.44)+
  labs(title = "Most Prevalence Illness Over Time- Insured")



insured_uninsured_find_highest("Uninsured")



  


Uninsured_graphic+
  gghighlight(percentage<0.16, percentage>0.109, label_key=illness)+
  labs(title = "Most Prevalence Illness Over Time- Uninsured")




According to the graphic above, “Hay fever or respiratory allergy” is the most common illness for both “Insured” and “Uninsured” status.

objectID: Final project-Health conditions among children under age 18.html#question-2
href: Final project-Health conditions among children under age 18.html#question-2
title: Final Project- Demo
text:
Question 2

Question 2.1 What does the percent in the poverty level categories mean? How do we reorder the categories based on the definition?
The percentage is computed using U.S. Census Bureau poverty thresholds and family income and size information(“Health Conditions Among Children Under Age 18, by Selected Characteristics: United States, Average Annual, Selected Years 19971999 Through 20162018” 2019). It can used to set the “poverty lines.” (“2024 Federal Poverty Levels / Guidelines & How They Determine Medicaid Eligibility” 2024). The way to understand the percentage could be, for instance, the annual income for the “400% or more” percentage level is four times the annual income for the 100% level. Accordingly, the order for the categories within the poverty level should be “Below 100%”, “100%-199%”, “200%-399%”, and “400% or more.”

reorder_poverty_level <- health_clean %>%
  filter(str_detect(characteristics , "poverty"))%>%
   mutate(sub_name=factor(sub_name,levels=c("Below 100%", "100%-199%", "200%-399%","400% or more")))

reorder_poverty_level



  





Question 2.2 Which poverty level has a higher percentage?

poverty_level<- reorder_poverty_level%>%
  group_by(sub_name, year, year_number)%>%
  summarise(median= median(percentage))%>%
  mutate(median= median/100)

poverty_level %>%
  ggplot(aes(year_number, median, col=sub_name))+
  geom_line()+
  geom_point()+
  ggthemes::theme_few()+
  scale_x_continuous(n.break=14, name= "Year Number")+
  scale_y_continuous(label = scales::percent, name = " Median Percentage for various poverty level", n.breaks = 10)+
  scale_color_discrete(name="poverty level")+
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")+
  labs(title = "Trends For Various Poverty Level Over Time")+

text:
Preparing for the Question 3 and Question 4
As questions 3 and 4 are based on the trend of percentages for various illnesses over time, this part aims to prepare for future analysis, which presents the trend of percentages for various illnesses over time.

illness_median <- health_clean %>%
  group_by(illness, year, `year_number`)%>%
  summarise(median= median(percentage))%>%
  ungroup()%>%
  mutate(median=median/100)%>%
  mutate(labels=scales::percent(median))

illness_median



  


illness_change_over_time <- illness_median%>%
  ggplot(aes(year_number, median, col= illness))+
  geom_line()+
  geom_point()+
  ggthemes::theme_few()+
  scale_x_continuous(n.break=8, name= "Year Number")+
  scale_y_continuous(label = scales::percent, name = "Percentage of illness")+
  scale_color_brewer(palette = "Dark2", name= "Illness")+
   guides(col=guide_legend(nrow=4))+
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")+
  labs(title = "Trends For Various Illness Over Time")+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust=0.5))+
  theme(strip.text = element_text(size=7))

illness_change_over_time

The trends for all characteristics over time are going down, except the “Two or more races” in the “Race” category.
Based on “Hay fever or respiratory allergy” illness, the higher percentage for the different poverty levels over time is different from the previous analysis for the poverty level. The reason for the differences might be the analysis in question 2 includes multiple illnesses and is based on the percentage median.



Aged between 10-17 years old, Males are more likely to get “Hay fever or respiratory allergy” over time compared to other ages (which refers to 0-4 years old, 5-17 years old, and 5-9 years old) and sex groups (which refers to female).

text:
Clean the data set
To clean the data, delete the columns that include some repeat information, like the number representing the variables, the columns that only include one piece of information, like the “INDICATOR” column, and the rows that contain the not available cells, are necessary. Besides, arranging the table through “PANEL” and “YEAR,” renaming the column, and using the information in the “SE” column (standard error) to calculate the upper and lower percentage information will make the table more in order and easier to understand.

health_clean <- health %>%
  select(- ("PANEL_NUM"),
         - ("UNIT_NUM"),
         -("STUB_NAME_NUM"),
         -("STUB_LABEL_NUM"),
         -("AGE_NUM"),
         - ("INDICATOR"),
         - ("UNIT"),
         - ("AGE"),
         - ("FLAG"))%>%
  arrange(PANEL, YEAR)%>%
  na.omit()%>%
  rename("illness"=`PANEL`, "characteristics"=`STUB_NAME`, "sub_name"=`STUB_LABEL`, "year"= `YEAR`, "year_number"= `YEAR_NUM`, "percentage"=`ESTIMATE`, "se"=`SE`) %>%
   mutate(illness= str_remove(illness, "among persons under 18 years"))%>%
  mutate("percentage_high"= percentage+se, "percentage_low"= percentage-se )
  

health_clean

text:
Research questions

How to combine the “Insured” sub-categories? After combination, which insurance status is higher? Insured or Uninsured? Which illness is more prevalent based on these two statuses?
What does the percent in the poverty level categories mean? How do we reorder the categories based on the definition? Which poverty level has a higher percentage? Which illness is more prevalent based on various poverty levels?
After display the trend of percentage for various illness over time, which illness is more prevalent over time? How does the percentage for different demographic characteristics change over time in this particular illness?
After display the trend of percentage for various illness over time, which percentage of children with illness increased most over time? How does this particular illness’s percentage of demographic characteristics change over time?

text:
Analysis

Question 1

Question 1.1 How to combine the “Insured” sub-categories?

insured_uninsured_calculate <- function(x) {

table <- health_clean %>%
  filter(str_detect(illness, x)& str_detect(characteristics, "insurance"))%>%
  mutate(sub_name= str_remove(sub_name, ": Medicaid$|: Private$"))

 Insured <- table %>%
  filter(str_detect(sub_name,"Insured")) %>%
group_by(illness, characteristics, sub_name, year, year_number) %>%
  summarise(percentage= sum(percentage), percentage_high= sum(percentage_high), percentage_low= sum(percentage_low))

 Uninsured <- table %>%
  filter(str_detect(sub_name,"Uninsured"))%>%
   select(!se)
 
 table_final <- full_join(Insured, Uninsured)%>%
  mutate(percentage= percentage/100)%>%
    mutate(percentage_high=percentage_high/100)%>%
    mutate(percentage_low= percentage_low/100)
 
 return(table_final)}

illness_variable <- unique(health_clean$illness)

table_final_illness<- map_dfr(illness_variable, insured_uninsured_calculate)

table_final_illness



  



As mentioned in the “Overview” section, combine three categories under “Insured,” meaning full. Accordingly, this section uses functions like str_remove() and summaries(sum()) to achieve it.


Question 1.2 which insurance status is higher? Insured or Uninsured?

median_percentage_insured_uninsured <- table_final_illness%>%
  group_by(year, year_number, sub_name)%>%
  summarise(median=median(percentage))

median_percentage_insured_uninsured



  


median_percentage_insured_uninsured %>%
  ggplot(aes(year_number, median, col=sub_name))+
  geom_line()+
  geom_point()+
  ggthemes::theme_few()+
  scale_x_continuous(n.break=14, name= "Year Number")+
  scale_y_continuous(label = scales::percent, name = " Median percentage for various insruance status", n.breaks = 10)+
  scale_color_okabeito(name="Insurance Status")+
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")+
  labs(title = "Trends For Various Insurance Status Over Time")+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust=0.5))+
  theme(strip.text = element_text(size=7))




Based on the graphic above, it is easy to see that insured status has a higher median percentage.


Question 1.3 Which illness is more prevalent based on these two statuses?

According to the graphic above, “Hay fever or respiratory allergy” is the most common illness for both “Insured” and “Uninsured” status.



Question 2

Question 2.1 What does the percent in the poverty level categories mean? How do we reorder the categories based on the definition?
The percentage is computed using U.S. Census Bureau poverty thresholds and family income and size information(“Health Conditions Among Children Under Age 18, by Selected Characteristics: United States, Average Annual, Selected Years 19971999 Through 20162018” 2019). It can used to set the “poverty lines.” (“2024 Federal Poverty Levels / Guidelines & How They Determine Medicaid Eligibility” 2024). The way to understand the percentage could be, for instance, the annual income for the “400% or more” percentage level is four times the annual income for the 100% level. Accordingly, the order for the categories within the poverty level should be “Below 100%”, “100%-199%”, “200%-399%”, and “400% or more.”

reorder_poverty_level <- health_clean %>%
  filter(str_detect(characteristics , "poverty"))%>%
   mutate(sub_name=factor(sub_name,levels=c("Below 100%", "100%-199%", "200%-399%","400% or more")))

reorder_poverty_level

  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust=0.5))+
  theme(strip.text = element_text(size=7))+
   guides(col=guide_legend(nrow=2))

Preparing for the Question 3 and Question 4
As questions 3 and 4 are based on the trend of percentages for various illnesses over time, this part aims to prepare for future analysis, which presents the trend of percentages for various illnesses over time.

illness_median <- health_clean %>%
  group_by(illness, year, `year_number`)%>%
  summarise(median= median(percentage))%>%
  ungroup()%>%
  mutate(median=median/100)%>%
  mutate(labels=scales::percent(median))

illness_median



  


illness_change_over_time <- illness_median%>%
  ggplot(aes(year_number, median, col= illness))+
  geom_line()+
  geom_point()+
  ggthemes::theme_few()+
  scale_x_continuous(n.break=8, name= "Year Number")+
  scale_y_continuous(label = scales::percent, name = "Percentage of illness")+
  scale_color_brewer(palette = "Dark2", name= "Illness")+
   guides(col=guide_legend(nrow=4))+
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")+
  labs(title = "Trends For Various Illness Over Time")+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust=0.5))+
  theme(strip.text = element_text(size=7))

illness_change_over_time

Question 3.2 How does the percentage for different demographic characteristics change over time in this particular illness?

characteristic_division_respiratory <- function(x) {
health_clean %>%
  filter(str_detect(illness,"respiratory"))%>%
  mutate(percentage= percentage/100)%>%
    mutate(percentage_high=percentage_high/100)%>%
    mutate(percentage_low= percentage_low/100)%>%
  filter(str_detect(characteristics,x)) }

Visualization <- function (df) {
  
  df%>%
   ggplot(aes(year_number, percentage, col=sub_name))+
 geom_line()+
    geom_point()+
  ggthemes::theme_few()+
  scale_x_continuous(n.break=14, name= "Year Number")+
  scale_y_continuous(label = scales::percent, name = "Percentage of characteristics", n.breaks = 10)+
    geom_errorbar(aes(ymin=percentage_high,ymax=percentage_low, width=0.5))+
  scale_color_discrete(name= "Sub-name of characteristics")+
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust=0.5))
}

Some observation for the graphics above:

The trends for all characteristics over time are going down, except the “Two or more races” in the “Race” category.
Based on “Hay fever or respiratory allergy” illness, the higher percentage for the different poverty levels over time is different from the previous analysis for the poverty level. The reason for the differences might be the analysis in question 2 includes multiple illnesses and is based on the percentage median.



Aged between 10-17 years old, Males are more likely to get “Hay fever or respiratory allergy” over time compared to other ages (which refers to 0-4 years old, 5-17 years old, and 5-9 years old) and sex groups (which refers to female).
